intro: Carum peregrinum, commonly known as the wandering chervil, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained soils. Its seeds are often used in culinary applications, adding a delicate anise-like flavor to dishes. Carum peregrinum is also valued in traditional medicine for its purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties.
